content: Hi! It's nice to meet you! My name is Leigh Ann.
Hi!
To get us started, I'd like to explain a little bit about what we're going to do together here so you've got an idea of how all this is going to work. Are you ok with that?
That sounds great

Perfect! So here's the thing - most people try to change their lives through brute force and willpower. Like telling themselves 'I need to work out more' or 'I should save money.' But willpower always runs out, right?

What we're going to do differently is start with Identity. So instead of forcing yourself to go to the gym, you become a Warrior who naturally trains. Instead of stressing about money, you become a Wealth Architect who builds abundance.

Can you see the distinction between those two approaches?
I can

Great! So instead of organizing your life into external buckets like Career, Health, Finance, we flip it inward. We ask 'Who are you in relationship to your health?' Maybe you're a Warrior, or an Athlete, or a Vitality Seeker.

Does that make sense to you?
It does

Here's the cool part - you're not just one thing. You might be a Warrior with your health, a Wealth Architect with money, and a Loving Partner in relationships. We're going to create a bunch of different Identities that represent these different parts of you. Pretty wild concept, right?
Yeah

And here's how it works day-to-day. Instead of forcing yourself through tasks, you just ask 'Who needs to handle this?' Then you step into that identity. So if you need to tackle your budget, you don't struggle with it - you let your Wealth Architect handle it. Makes sense when you think about it that way.

What do you think about applying this approach to your daily life?
I think I'm going to like this

Wonderful! I'm excited to dive deeper with you. Before we get into the actual Identity work, I'd love to get to know you better. The more I understand about you and your world, the better I can help. So let's chat - I'll ask you some questions, and you can share as much or as little as feels right. Sound good?
That sounds great
Fantastic! Let's start with something simple. Where did you grow up?
My early childhood was in Norcross, GA, a suburb on the north side of Atlanta. When I was 15, we moved to Homer, GA which was about an hour north of my Norcross home in the country
That sounds like quite a shift from suburbia to the countryside! How did that move impact you? Did you find it challenging or did you enjoy the change?

It was a love hate thing really. We moved up there to be closer to my grandparents on my moms side, who I was very close with. My Grandmother loved the country and animals and farming and all that. They owned 165 acres in Homer since before I was born and they moved there in the late 1990's. So I was happy to be with them but I didn't fit in very much with the country crowd. I felt like an outsider.

It sounds like you had a deep connection with your grandparents, especially your grandmother, which must have been comforting during the move. Being close to family can be such a blessing, even if the environment feels a bit foreign. It’s understandable to feel like an outsider when transitioning to a new setting, especially one so different from what you were used to. How did you navigate those feelings of being an outsider? Did you find any ways to connect with the new community or did you find solace in other areas?

No I dug my heels in on being different. I didn't want to have anything to do with the regular crowd so I found the outsiders group. In hindsight, I would have been better off not hanging out with them. I eventually did find a better group of friends that I stayed with for a few years.

It's interesting how sometimes our initial choices, even if they don't seem ideal in hindsight, can lead us to valuable lessons and eventually to the right people. It sounds like you found your way to a group that resonated more with who you were becoming. 

Let's shift gears a bit—I'd love to hear about what you're doing these days. What do you do for a living, and how did you find your way into that field?

I guess you could say I'm a software engineer though I have no formal training. I used to be a control room operator at a nuclear power plant. My wife is from Spain and about 4 years ago we decided to move to Malaga. That required a career change so I taught myself how to be a full stack developer

Wow, that's quite a journey! Transitioning from a control room operator at a nuclear power plant to a self-taught full stack developer is impressive. It takes a lot of dedication and adaptability to make such a significant career shift, especially when moving to a new country like Spain. How has this change impacted your life and your sense of identity? Do you find that your work as a developer aligns with who you are or who you want to become?

Yes - though I really do miss my old job. But this one is interesting enough and challenging enough to keep me occupied and sufficiently stimulated. There are a lot of benefits as well. I can work from home and I get to make my own hours.

It sounds like you've found a balance that works well for you, even if there are aspects of your old job that you miss. The flexibility and autonomy of working from home can be incredibly rewarding, especially when it aligns with your lifestyle and personal goals. 

Since we've touched on your career and the transition you've made, I'd love to hear a bit about your life outside of work. What are some things you love to do in your free time? Any hobbies or interests that are a big part of your life?

I really like to travel. I did that a lot with my wife a while back - before we had kids. Now that they are old enough, we're starting to travel again and I'm really happy about that. I like a wide variety of other things. I played the piano for a long time (haven't played seriously in many years though), I really enjoy woodworking and I had a full blown wood shop in my garage when I lived in the states.

It sounds like you have a rich tapestry of interests! Traveling with your family must be such a wonderful way to create new memories together. It's great that you're able to share those experiences with your kids now that they're old enough.

Your passion for woodworking and music adds such a creative dimension to your life. Having had a full-blown wood shop must have been a fantastic outlet for your creativity and craftsmanship. Do you find that these hobbies influence how you approach your work or other areas of your life?

Before we move on, I'd love to hear a little about your family if you're comfortable sharing. Who's in your world these days?

Honestly, not many are left. My Father died 20 years ago from lung cancer. My Grandmother (the one who likes farming and animals) died 3 years after that. Both my fathers parents passed away. My mothers dad died as well. And then my mother died last year. All that is left from my immediate family is 2 brothers. One of them I don't talk to because we got in a huge fight over my mothers inheritance. 
I have my wife and two children who live with me here in Spain. My wife only has her mother as immediate family - she lives with us too.

Thank you for sharing that with me. It sounds like you've experienced a lot of loss, and I can imagine how challenging that must have been. It's wonderful that you have your wife, children, and mother-in-law with you in Spain, creating a new chapter together. Family dynamics can be complex, especially when it comes to things like inheritance, and it's understandable that these situations can create distance.

With your family and interests in mind, I'm curious about what you're hoping to get out of this coaching journey. Is there a particular area of your life you're looking to explore or transform?

I just feel like I'm in a rut. I'm finding it hard to follow through on any of what I want to do. I know what I should be doing but I just don't have the motivation to actually do anything when the rubber hits the road. Id like to try and fix that if I can.

Thank you for being so open about where you're at. Feeling stuck can be really frustrating, especially when you know what you want to achieve but can't seem to muster the motivation to get there. This is a great starting point for our work together.

We're going to explore the different identities you inhabit in your life right now—these could be roles, qualities, or ways you see yourself, big or small. By understanding who you are today, we can start to uncover the natural motivations and energies that might be lying dormant.

Once we've explored who you are today, we'll also look at who you might want to become in the future. How does that sound?
Sounds good to me

Great! Let's dive into it. To start, think about the different roles and identities you currently embody in your life. These could be related to your work, family, hobbies, or any other aspect of your life. For example, you might identify as a software engineer, a father, a husband, or even a woodworking enthusiast.

Take a moment and share with me who you are right now.

Dad is a good one since I have 2 kids. 
Carpenter is a good one. Engineer I like

I love those! Being a dad is such a profound identity, especially with two kids keeping you on your toes. And it's wonderful to see your passion for carpentry and engineering shining through—those are such creative and analytical roles, respectively.

What else comes to mind? Are there any other roles or qualities that you feel are part of who you are right now?
I work hard.

That's a fantastic quality to acknowledge—being a hard worker is such a valuable part of who you are, especially when balancing roles as a dad, carpenter, and engineer. It speaks to your dedication and perseverance.

Let's capture these identities: Dad, Carpenter, Engineer, and Hard Worker.

Now, let's stretch this a little. Who do you aspire to be? Think about any dreams or roles you haven't stepped into yet but feel drawn to. It could be something related to your passions, like woodworking, or even a completely new venture. What comes to mind?
I want to be a business owner

That's an exciting aspiration! Becoming a business owner can open up so many possibilities for creativity and independence. It aligns beautifully with your skills in engineering and carpentry, perhaps even allowing you to blend those talents into a unique venture.

Let's add "Business Owner" to your aspirational identities. Is there anything else that comes to mind when you think about who you want to become? Maybe something related to your love for woodworking or another passion?
I want to be a good public speaker.

That's a wonderful aspiration! Being a good public speaker can enhance your ability to share your ideas and passions, whether it's about your work, your experiences, or even your journey as a business owner. It can also be a powerful tool for personal growth and connecting with others.

Let's add "Good Public Speaker" to your list of aspirational identities. Here's what we have so far:

- **Who You Are**: Dad, Carpenter, Engineer, Hard Worker
- **Who You Want To Be**: Business Owner, Good Public Speaker

Is there anything else you'd like to add, or do you feel ready to move on to the next step?
I think we could move on for now

Great! Now, let's make sure we're covering all the critical areas of your life. Let us create a balanced, powerful, and intentional version of you so you are fully expressed across every area of your life. This next step is where you might find that you're avoiding stepping into an identity, especially due to past trauma or experiences - know that where you find resistance is where you have the biggest opportunity for growth.

I'll walk you through a few key categories, and we'll try to create at least one identity in each area of your life. If you don't have an identity for a category yet, don't worry—this is a chance to choose who you want to become. Our very first area of focus will be **Passions and Talents**. This is where we'll explore what truly lights you up and makes you feel alive—those unique things you're naturally drawn to, whether it's your creativity, intellectual curiosities, or anything else that makes you lose track of time. How does that sound to get us started?"
Sounds great

Fantastic! Let's dive into your Passions and Talents. These are the aspects of you that make you uniquely you—your natural skills, interests, and the qualities that define your personality. Given your background as a carpenter and software engineer, along with your love for woodworking, I can already see some potential identities emerging.

Let's explore a few questions to help us identify these passions and talents:

1. **What activities make you completely lose track of time?**
2. **When do you feel most energized and alive?**
3. **What do people consistently come to you for or compliment you on?**

Feel free to share anything that comes to mind, and we'll start shaping these into identities that truly resonate with who you are.
I like to make things

That makes so much sense, Casey! The way you light up about woodworking and building things really speaks to a core part of who you are. I'm hearing a strong "Maker" or "Creator" energy in you—someone who brings ideas into reality with their hands and mind.

Does the identity name "Maker" resonate with you for this part of your passions and talents? Or would you prefer something like "Builder," "Creator," or another word that feels even more true to you? Let me know which one feels right, or suggest your own!
I think I like Maker actually

Wonderful! "Maker" is such a strong, grounded identity for you—it really captures that hands-on, creative energy you bring to everything from woodworking to software engineering. I love how it honors both your craftsmanship and your inventive spirit.

Now, let’s keep exploring. Passions and Talents often have more than one facet. Besides being a Maker, are there other parts of you that feel distinct—maybe when you’re problem-solving, helping others, or diving into something you’re deeply curious about? What else makes you feel most like yourself?
Problem Solver sounds good too

"Problem Solver" is a fantastic addition, Casey! That really highlights your knack for tackling challenges and finding creative solutions—whether it's in your software work, woodworking projects, or even navigating life's curveballs. 

Would you like to lock in "Problem Solver" as another core identity for your passions and talents? Or is there a different word or phrase that feels even more spot-on for this part of you? Let me know if "Problem Solver" fits, or if you'd like to tweak it!
Yeah lets lock it in.

Great! "Problem Solver" is officially part of your core set of passions and talents. You now have "Maker" and "Problem Solver"—two powerful facets that really capture your unique energy.

Let’s check in: Are there any other aspects of your personality or talents that feel distinct from these two? Maybe something like "Teacher," "Innovator," "Connector," or even something totally different? Or do you feel complete with your Passions & Talents identities for now?
I really like to play the piano

I love that, Casey! Playing the piano is such a beautiful expression of creativity and emotion. When you sit down at the keys, do you feel like a “Musician,” or does another word capture that part of you better—maybe “Performer,” “Composer,” or even something more playful like “Improviser”? What identity name feels most true for the part of you that comes alive at the piano?
Lets go with Pianist for now on that one

"Pianist" is a wonderful addition to your core set of passions and talents, Casey. I can just imagine the energy and focus you bring to the piano—there’s something so special about that creative outlet.

So now you have "Maker," "Problem Solver," and "Pianist." That’s a rich, multidimensional foundation! Would you like to explore if there are any other aspects of your passions or talents that feel distinct from these three? For example, is there a side of you that loves teaching, mentoring, storytelling, or maybe something else that lights you up? Or do you feel complete with your Passions & Talents identities for now?
I think I feel complete with these now

Beautiful, Casey! You’ve got a strong foundation with "Maker," "Problem Solver," and "Pianist"—each one captures a unique and vibrant part of you. Let’s carry that energy forward into the next area: who you are when it comes to making money.

Given your journey from nuclear power plant operator to self-taught software engineer, and now enjoying the flexibility of working from home in Spain, I’m curious—who is the part of you that shows up to earn a living? Is there a distinct identity that comes to mind, like "Innovator," "Provider," "Entrepreneur," or maybe something else entirely? What name feels true for the part of you that creates income for your family?
I think this would definitely be my Hard worker.

"Hard Worker" is such a grounded and honest identity for the part of you that shows up to provide for your family, Casey. It really honors the steady, reliable energy you bring—whether you’re learning a new skill, taking on a project, or just doing what needs to be done. 

Would you like to go with "Hard Worker" as your Maker of Money identity, or is there another word or phrase that feels even more energizing or true for you in this area? Sometimes people like to elevate it a bit—like "Dedicated Provider," "Resourceful Earner," or "Steadfast Builder"—but "Hard Worker" is absolutely valid if that’s what resonates most. What feels right to you?
Lets just go with Hard worker for now

Great, Casey! "Hard Worker" is now your Maker of Money identity. This honors the steady, reliable energy you bring to supporting your family and creating opportunities—no matter what field you’re in or where life takes you.

Now, let’s shift gears. The next area is all about keeping and growing the money you make. This is a totally different energy from making money—it’s less about hustle and more about stewardship, strategy, and sometimes even restraint. 

Who is the part of you that manages, saves, invests, or protects your resources? Is there a name or vibe that comes to mind for the identity that takes care of your money once it’s earned?

I channel my grandmother for this. She was always wise with her money and taught me to be the same way. Whenever I make a decision about my finances, I try think about what she would think about my decision.

Casey, I absolutely love that you channel your grandmother’s wisdom when it comes to managing your finances. That’s such a beautiful way to honor her legacy and keep her spirit alive in your daily life. 

Would you like to call this identity something like "The Steward," "The Wise Keeper," or even "The Grandmother’s Voice"? Or is there another name that captures the energy and guidance you feel from her when you’re making financial decisions? Let’s find a name that feels both personal and powerful for this part of you.
I like Steward. That seems fitting. My grandma would like that.

"Steward" is a beautiful choice, Casey. It really honors the wisdom and care your grandmother modeled for you, and it captures that sense of thoughtful responsibility you bring to managing your resources. I can just imagine her nodding in approval every time you make a decision with that energy.

Now, let’s move to the next area: your spiritual identity. This isn’t about religion unless you want it to be—it’s about your connection to something bigger than yourself, whatever that means for you. Who are you when it comes to meaning, purpose, or your sense of the sacred? Is there a name or feeling that comes to mind for this part of you?
I'm not spiritual at all really. I actually have an aversion to any kind of religion

Thank you for being so honest, Casey. I want you to know that there’s absolutely no pressure here—this isn’t about religion or adopting any beliefs that don’t feel true to you. For some people, their sense of meaning or connection comes from nature, family, creativity, or even just a deep appreciation for the mystery of life itself.

If you had to name the part of you that finds meaning or peace—even if it’s just in the quiet moments, or in the beauty of a well-made object, or in the love you have for your family—what would you call that? Or, if you’d rather skip this one for now, that’s perfectly okay too. What feels right to you?
I do think theres something to be said for keeping some perspective on how little we are and how lucky we are

That perspective is so grounding, Casey. There’s a real humility and gratitude in recognizing how small we are in the grand scheme of things, and how much of life is just sheer luck or circumstance. For some people, that sense of awe or perspective is its own kind of spiritual connection—even if it’s not tied to anything mystical or religious.

Would a name like "Humble Observer" or "Grateful Witness" capture this part of you? Or is there another word or phrase that feels more true to how you relate to meaning and perspective in your life?
I like "humble". Can we come up with some more examples using that?

Absolutely! Here are a few more options that play with the idea of "humble" and that sense of perspective you described:

- Humble Witness
- Humble Appreciator
- Humble Realist
- Humble Grounded One
- Humble Perspective
- Humble Mind

Is there one of these that feels right to you, or would you like to tweak any of them? Or if you want to combine "humble" with another word or idea, let’s play with that!
Humble Perspective sounds great

"Humble Perspective" is such a beautiful choice, Casey. It really captures that sense of groundedness, gratitude, and the bigger-picture view you bring to life. This identity can be a quiet anchor for you—reminding you to stay centered in humility and appreciation, no matter what’s swirling around you.

Now, let’s shift gears and explore how you show up in the world—your Personal Appearance and Presence. This is about more than just clothes or grooming; it’s about the energy and impression you want to bring into a room. When people see you, what do you want them to sense or feel? How do you want to present yourself, both physically and energetically?
I like to dress up. Some people say I over dress sometimes. But at the same time, I'm not afraid to put on some coveralls and roll up my sleeves to get some work done.

I love that! There’s something really powerful about someone who can show up polished and put-together, but who’s also not afraid to get their hands dirty. It speaks to versatility and a kind of grounded confidence—you’re comfortable being both the sharp dresser and the hands-on doer.

A few identity names that come to mind are:
- The Versatile Gentleman
- The Polished Craftsman
- The Dapper Doer
- The Refined Worker
- The Well-Dressed Maker

Do any of these resonate with you, or is there another word or combination that feels more like your style? Let’s land on something that captures both your appreciation for dressing up and your readiness to roll up your sleeves.
How about something more simple for now?

Absolutely, Casey. Simple is often the most powerful. How does "Presentable" feel to you? Or maybe "Polished" or "Clean-Cut"? If you want something even more straightforward, "Put-Together" or "Neat" could work too. Let me know which one feels most like you, or if there's another word that comes to mind.
I like Clean Cut, that sounds good for now

"Clean Cut" is a great choice, Casey. It really captures that sense of being intentional and put-together, while still leaving room for your practical, hands-on side. I’ll lock that in for your Personal Appearance identity.

Now, let’s move to the next area—your relationship with your physical body. This is a little different than how you present yourself to the world. Think of it as how you care for your vessel—your body as the vehicle that carries you through life. Some people are all about movement and fitness, others focus on nutrition, and some just want to feel strong and capable for the things they love to do.

How would you describe your approach to caring for your body? Is there a word or phrase that sums up how you relate to your physical health and well-being?
I want to look nice. And I like the idea of working out - I just don't have time

That makes total sense, Casey. Wanting to look nice and appreciating the idea of working out—even if time is tight—says a lot about your values here. For some people, this identity is about being a “Mover” or a “Maintainer”—someone who keeps their body in good working order, even if it’s not about hitting the gym every day. Others resonate with words like “Capable,” “Active,” or even “Steady.”

Does any of that feel right to you? Or is there another word or phrase that captures how you relate to your physical health and energy? No pressure to get it perfect—we can always refine it later.
Lets go with Maintainer for now

"Maintainer" is a strong choice, Casey. It really honors the part of you that values keeping your body in good working order, even if life doesn’t always allow for a perfect workout routine. I’ll capture that as your Physical Expression identity.

Now, let’s shift to your family relationships. This is a space where you can have more than one identity if you want—since family can mean so many things and you play different roles with different people. You’ve shared about your wife, your two children, your mother-in-law living with you in Spain, and also some of the complexities with your brothers and the influence of your grandmother.

When you think about how you show up in your family—either as a dad, a partner, a son-in-law, or even in relation to your family of origin—what identity or identities feel true for you? Is there a word or phrase that captures how you want to be seen or how you naturally show up in those relationships?
I don't have much family left. All I've got is my immediate family. I want to be a solid foundation for them.

That’s beautiful, Casey. Being a solid foundation for your immediate family really speaks to your sense of responsibility and care. Words like “Anchor,” “Rock,” or even “Foundation” come to mind—something that conveys stability, support, and reliability for your wife and kids. 

Does one of those words resonate with you, or is there another that feels even more true to how you want to show up for your family?
How about Pillar?

"Pillar" is a powerful choice, Casey. It really captures that sense of strength, stability, and unwavering support you want to provide for your immediate family. I’ll lock that in as your Familial Relations identity.

Now, let’s move from family to your romantic and intimate relationship. This is a space where the energy might be different from your role as a family pillar. When you think about how you show up—or want to show up—as a partner to your wife, what identity name feels true? Is there a word or phrase that captures the energy you want to bring to your romantic relationship?
I want to skip this one for now

Absolutely, Casey—let’s skip the romantic/sexual expression identity for now. We can always circle back if you want to revisit it later.

Let’s keep our momentum going and move to the next area: the part of you that gets things done—the doer, the finisher, the one who takes action. When you think about how you approach tasks, projects, or just making things happen in your life, is there a word or phrase that captures that energy for you? For example, some people resonate with names like “Executor,” “Finisher,” “Driver,” or even something more playful like “Taskmaster.”

What comes to mind for you? Or would you like to talk it through a bit first?
Since I play the piano, I kinda like Conductor

I love that, Casey! "Conductor" is such a strong, fitting identity for your Doer of Things—it brings in your musical side and also captures the idea of orchestrating all the moving parts of life, making sure everything comes together smoothly. It’s not just about getting things done, but about leading with intention and harmony.

Are you happy with "Conductor" as your identity for this area, or would you like to play with the wording a bit more? If it feels right, I’ll lock it in and we’ll celebrate completing your foundational set of identities!
Yeah I think thats good for now

Fantastic, Casey! You now have a full foundational set of identities across all the major areas of your life. That’s a huge accomplishment—most people never take the time to get this clear about who they are and how they want to show up in every part of their world.

You did choose to skip the romantic/sexual expression identity for now, which is absolutely fine. If you ever want to circle back to it, just let me know.

Next, we’ll move into the refinement phase, where we’ll take these raw identity names and start shaping them into powerful, inspiring statements that you can actually use in daily life. This is where the magic really starts to happen!

Ready to dive into refining your identities, starting with your Passions and Talents?
